scenario:
Dividend-paying stocks have historically provided higher returns than non-dividend paying stocks, with an average annual total return of 10.19% for dividend growers and initiators from 1973 to 2023. This is compared to 9.17% for dividend payers, 6.74% for no change in dividend policy, 4.27% for dividend non-payers, and -0.63% for dividend shrinkers and eliminators. The equal-weighted S&P 500 index returned 7.72% over the same period.

Investing in dividend-paying stocks can be done through individual stocks or exchange-traded funds (ETFs). Some individual stocks with high dividend yields include Altria (7.62%), Dow (7.08%), and Verizon Communications (6.65%). However, it's essential to research and evaluate stocks carefully to avoid high-yield companies in trouble.

Dividend-focused ETFs offer an easier way to invest in dividend payers, with instant diversification across hundreds of dividend payers. Some popular dividend ETFs include the SPDR Portfolio S&P 500 High Dividend ETF (SPYD), Schwab U.S. Dividend Equity ETF (SCHD), and Vanguard High Dividend Yield ETF (VYM). These ETFs have provided average annual returns ranging from 4.39% to 12.82% over the past 5-10 years.

Investing in dividend-paying stocks can be a powerful wealth builder, especially when combined with regular contributions. For example, investing $6,000 per year at an 8% annual return can grow to $593,076 over 40 years, while investing $12,000 per year can grow to $3,357,372.
